text.p: Following are reactions to first quarter GDP data released by Statistics Canada on Monday.
Economists in a Reuters survey had forecast a 1.0 percent rise in the first quarter.:

"I think they're a little weaker than anticipated at 3.4 percent, but a lot of that is due to inventories. So in general that suggests to me that we've got a pretty broad-based expansion underway. Most of the categories of final domestic demand are very strong for the quarter," said Rick Egelton, deputy chief economist at the Bank of Montreal.

"The headline number, 3.4 percent growth is a little bit misleading. If you take a look at final domestic demand it rose 6.4 percent," said Mark Chandler, senior economist with Goldman Sachs Canada. "Going forward what you're likely to see is further stock building and continued growth in those sectors that drove us in the first quarter."
"The GDP figure is a lot stronger than the headline 3.4 percent number suggests," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Inc.
"All the domestic components, other than the government sector, were very strong."
